sentences: Then, Socrates, let us begin by clearing up these questions.

187.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: That is what I should wish.

188.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: And I am sure that all my other friends will be glad to hear them discussed; Philebus, fortunately for us, is not disposed to move, and we had better not stir him up with questions.

189.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Good; and where shall we begin this great and multifarious battle, in which such various points are at issue?
Shall we begin thus?

190.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How?

191.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: We say that the one and many become identified by thought, and that now, as in time past, they run about together, in and out of every word which is uttered, and that this union of them will never cease, and is not now beginning, but is, as I believe, an everlasting quality of thought itself, which never grows old.

Any young man, when he first tastes these subtleties, is delighted, and fancies that he has found a treasure of wisdom; in the first enthusiasm of his joy he leaves no stone, or rather no thought unturned, now rolling up the many into the one, and kneading them together, now unfolding and dividing them; he puzzles himself first and above all, and then he proceeds to puzzle his neighbours, whether they are older or younger, or of his own age—that makes no difference; neither father nor mother does he spare; no human being who has ears is safe from him, hardly even his dog, and a barbarian would have no chance of escaping him, if an interpreter could only be found.

192.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Considering, Socrates, how many we are, and that all of us are young men, is there not a danger that we and Philebus may all set upon you, if you abuse us?
We understand what you mean; but is there no charm by which we may dispel all this confusion, no more excellent way of arriving at the truth?
If there is, we hope that you will guide us into that way, and we will do our best to follow, for the enquiry in which we are engaged, Socrates, is not unimportant.

193.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The reverse of unimportant, my boys, as Philebus calls you, and there neither is nor ever will be a better than my own favourite way, which has nevertheless already often deserted me and left me helpless in the hour of need.

194.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Tell us what that is.

195.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: One which may be easily pointed out, but is by no means easy of application; it is the parent of all the discoveries in the arts.

196.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Tell us what it is.

197.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: A gift of heaven, which, as I conceive, the gods tossed among men by the hands of a new Prometheus, and therewith a blaze of light; and the ancients, who were our betters and nearer the gods than we are, handed down the tradition, that whatever things are said to be are composed of one and many, and have the finite and infinite implanted in them:  seeing, then, that such is the order of the world, we too ought in every enquiry to begin by laying down one idea of that which is the subject of enquiry; this unity we shall find in everything.

Having found it, we may next proceed to look for two, if there be two, or, if not, then for three or some other number, subdividing each of these units, until at last the unity with which we began is seen not only to be one and many and infinite, but also a definite number; the infinite must not be suffered to approach the many until the entire number of the species intermediate between unity and infinity has been discovered,—then, and not till then, we may rest from division, and without further troubling ourselves about the endless individuals may allow them to drop into infinity.
This, as I was saying, is the way of considering and learning and teaching one another, which the gods have handed down to us.
But the wise men of our time are either too quick or too slow in conceiving plurality in unity.
Having no method, they make their one and many anyhow, and from unity pass at once to infinity; the intermediate steps never occur to them.
And this, I repeat, is what makes the difference between the mere art of disputation and true dialectic.

198.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I think that I partly understand you Socrates, but I should like to have a clearer notion of what you are saying.

199.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I may illustrate my meaning by the letters of the alphabet, Protarchus, which you were made to learn as a child.

200.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How do they afford an illustration?

201.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The sound which passes through the lips whether of an individual or of all men is one and yet infinite.

202.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

203.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And yet not by knowing either that sound is one or that sound is infinite are we perfect in the art of speech, but the knowledge of the number and nature of sounds is what makes a man a grammarian.

204.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

205.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the knowledge which makes a man a musician is of the same kind.

206.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How so?

207.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Sound is one in music as well as in grammar?

208.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

209.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And there is a higher note and a lower note, and a note of equal pitch: —may we affirm so much?

210.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

211.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But you would not be a real musician if this was all that you knew; though if you did not know this you would know almost nothing of music.

212.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Nothing.

213.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But when you have learned what sounds are high and what low, and the number and nature of the intervals and their limits or proportions, and the systems compounded out of them, which our fathers discovered, and have handed down to us who are their descendants under the name of harmonies; and the affections corresponding to them in the movements of the human body, which when measured by numbers ought, as they say, to be called rhythms and measures; and they tell us that the same principle should be applied to every one and many;—when, I say, you have learned all this, then, my dear friend, you are perfect; and you may be said to understand any other subject, when you have a similar grasp of it.

But the infinity of kinds and the infinity of individuals which there is in each of them, when not classified, creates in every one of us a state of infinite ignorance; and he who never looks for number in anything, will not himself be looked for in the number of famous men.

214.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I think that what Socrates is now saying is excellent, Philebus.

215.speaker: PHILEBUS
sentences: I think so too, but how do his words bear upon us and upon the argument?

216.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Philebus is right in asking that question of us, Protarchus.

217.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Indeed he is, and you must answer him.

218.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I will; but you must let me make one little remark first about these matters; I was saying, that he who begins with any individual unity, should proceed from that, not to infinity, but to a definite number, and now I say conversely, that he who has to begin with infinity should not jump to unity, but he should look about for some number representing a certain quantity, and thus out of all end in one.
And now let us return for an illustration of our principle to the case of letters.

219.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What do you mean?

220.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Some god or divine man, who in the Egyptian legend is said to have been Theuth, observing that the human voice was infinite, first distinguished in this infinity a certain number of vowels, and then other letters which had sound, but were not pure vowels (i.e., the semivowels); these too exist in a definite number; and lastly, he distinguished a third class of letters which we now call mutes, without voice and without sound, and divided these, and likewise the two other classes of vowels and semivowels, into the individual sounds, and told the number of them, and gave to each and all of them the name of letters; and observing that none of us could learn any one of them and not learn them all, and in consideration of this common bond which in a manner united them, he assigned to them all a single art, and this he called the art of grammar or letters.

221.speaker: PHILEBUS
sentences: The illustration, Protarchus, has assisted me in understanding the original statement, but I still feel the defect of which I just now complained.

222.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Are you going to ask, Philebus, what this has to do with the argument?

223.speaker: PHILEBUS
sentences: Yes, that is a question which Protarchus and I have been long asking.

224.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Assuredly you have already arrived at the answer to the question which, as you say, you have been so long asking?

225.speaker: PHILEBUS
sentences: How so?

226.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Did we not begin by enquiring into the comparative eligibility of pleasure and wisdom?

227.speaker: PHILEBUS
sentences: Certainly.

228.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And we maintain that they are each of them one?

229.speaker: PHILEBUS
sentences: True.

230.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the precise question to which the previous discussion desires an answer is, how they are one and also many (i.e., how they have one genus and many species), and are not at once infinite, and what number of species is to be assigned to either of them before they pass into infinity (i.e.
into the infinite number of individuals).

231.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That is a very serious question, Philebus, to which Socrates has ingeniously brought us round, and please to consider which of us shall answer him; there may be something ridiculous in my being unable to answer, and therefore imposing the task upon you, when I have undertaken the whole charge of the argument, but if neither of us were able to answer, the result methinks would be still more ridiculous.
Let us consider, then, what we are to do: —Socrates, if I understood him rightly, is asking whether there are not kinds of pleasure, and what is the number and nature of them, and the same of wisdom.

232.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Most true, O son of Callias; and the previous argument showed that if we are not able to tell the kinds of everything that has unity, likeness, sameness, or their opposites, none of us will be of the smallest use in any enquiry.

233.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That seems to be very near the truth, Socrates.
Happy would the wise man be if he knew all things, and the next best thing for him is that he should know himself.
Why do I say so at this moment?
I will tell you.
You, Socrates, have granted us this opportunity of conversing with you, and are ready to assist us in determining what is the best of human goods.

For when Philebus said that pleasure and delight and enjoyment and the like were the chief good, you answered—No, not those, but another class of goods; and we are constantly reminding ourselves of what you said, and very properly, in order that we may not forget to examine and compare the two.
And these goods, which in your opinion are to be designated as superior to pleasure, and are the true objects of pursuit, are mind and knowledge and understanding and art, and the like.

There was a dispute about which were the best, and we playfully threatened that you should not be allowed to go home until the question was settled; and you agreed, and placed yourself at our disposal.
And now, as children say, what has been fairly given cannot be taken back; cease then to fight against us in this way.

234.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: In what way?

235.speaker: PHILEBUS
sentences: Do not perplex us, and keep asking questions of us to which we have not as yet any sufficient answer to give; let us not imagine that a general puzzling of us all is to be the end of our discussion, but if we are unable to answer, do you answer, as you have promised.

Consider, then, whether you will divide pleasure and knowledge according to their kinds; or you may let the matter drop, if you are able and willing to find some other mode of clearing up our controversy.

236.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: If you say that, I have nothing to apprehend, for the words 'if you are willing' dispel all my fear; and, moreover, a god seems to have recalled something to my mind.

237.speaker: PHILEBUS
sentences: What is that?

238.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I remember to have heard long ago certain discussions about pleasure and wisdom, whether awake or in a dream I cannot tell; they were to the effect that neither the one nor the other of them was the good, but some third thing, which was different from them, and better than either.
If this be clearly established, then pleasure will lose the victory, for the good will cease to be identified with her: —Am I not right?

239.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

240.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And there will cease to be any need of distinguishing the kinds of pleasures, as I am inclined to think, but this will appear more clearly as we proceed.

241.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Capital, Socrates; pray go on as you propose.

242.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But, let us first agree on some little points.

243.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What are they?

244.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Is the good perfect or imperfect?

245.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: The most perfect, Socrates, of all things.

246.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And is the good sufficient?

247.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, certainly, and in a degree surpassing all other things.

248.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And no one can deny that all percipient beings desire and hunt after good, and are eager to catch and have the good about them, and care not for the attainment of anything which is not accompanied by good.

249.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That is undeniable.

250.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Now let us part off the life of pleasure from the life of wisdom, and pass them in review.

251.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How do you mean?

252.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let there be no wisdom in the life of pleasure, nor any pleasure in the life of wisdom, for if either of them is the chief good, it cannot be supposed to want anything, but if either is shown to want anything, then it cannot really be the chief good.

253.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Impossible.

254.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And will you help us to test these two lives?

255.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

256.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then answer.

257.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Ask.

258.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Would you choose, Protarchus, to live all your life long in the enjoyment of the greatest pleasures?

259.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly I should.

260.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Would you consider that there was still anything wanting to you if you had perfect pleasure?

261.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly not.

262.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Reflect; would you not want wisdom and intelligence and forethought, and similar qualities?
would you not at any rate want sight?

263.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Why should I?
Having pleasure I should have all things.

264.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Living thus, you would always throughout your life enjoy the greatest pleasures?

265.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I should.

266.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But if you had neither mind, nor memory, nor knowledge, nor true opinion, you would in the first place be utterly ignorant of whether you were pleased or not, because you would be entirely devoid of intelligence.

267.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

268.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And similarly, if you had no memory you would not recollect that you had ever been pleased, nor would the slightest recollection of the pleasure which you feel at any moment remain with you; and if you had no true opinion you would not think that you were pleased when you were; and if you had no power of calculation you would not be able to calculate on future pleasure, and your life would be the life, not of a man, but of an oyster or 'pulmo marinus.'
Could this be otherwise?

269.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: No.

270.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But is such a life eligible?

271.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I cannot answer you, Socrates; the argument has taken away from me the power of speech.

272.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: We must keep up our spirits;—let us now take the life of mind and examine it in turn.

273.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: And what is this life of mind?

274.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I want to know whether any one of us would consent to live, having wisdom and mind and knowledge and memory of all things, but having no sense of pleasure or pain, and wholly unaffected by these and the like feelings?

275.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Neither life, Socrates, appears eligible to me, nor is likely, as I should imagine, to be chosen by any one else.

276.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: What would you say, Protarchus, to both of these in one, or to one that was made out of the union of the two?

277.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Out of the union, that is, of pleasure with mind and wisdom?

278.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Yes, that is the life which I mean.

279.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: There can be no difference of opinion; not some but all would surely choose this third rather than either of the other two, and in addition to them.

280.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But do you see the consequence?

281.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: To be sure I do.
The consequence is, that two out of the three lives which have been proposed are neither sufficient nor eligible for man or for animal.

282.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then now there can be no doubt that neither of them has the good, for the one which had would certainly have been sufficient and perfect and eligible for every living creature or thing that was able to live such a life; and if any of us had chosen any other, he would have chosen contrary to the nature of the truly eligible, and not of his own free will, but either through ignorance or from some unhappy necessity.

283.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly that seems to be true.

284.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now have I not sufficiently shown that Philebus' goddess is not to be regarded as identical with the good?

285.speaker: PHILEBUS
sentences: Neither is your 'mind' the good, Socrates, for that will be open to the same objections.

286.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Perhaps, Philebus, you may be right in saying so of my 'mind'; but of the true, which is also the divine mind, far otherwise.
However, I will not at present claim the first place for mind as against the mixed life; but we must come to some understanding about the second place.
For you might affirm pleasure and I mind to be the cause of the mixed life; and in that case although neither of them would be the good, one of them might be imagined to be the cause of the good.
And I might proceed further to argue in opposition to Philebus, that the element which makes this mixed life eligible and good, is more akin and more similar to mind than to pleasure.
And if this is true, pleasure cannot be truly said to share either in the first or second place, and does not, if I may trust my own mind, attain even to the third.

287.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Truly, Socrates, pleasure appears to me to have had a fall; in fighting for the palm, she has been smitten by the argument, and is laid low.
I must say that mind would have fallen too, and may therefore be thought to show discretion in not putting forward a similar claim.
And if pleasure were deprived not only of the first but of the second place, she would be terribly damaged in the eyes of her admirers, for not even to them would she still appear as fair as before.

288.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, but had we not better leave her now, and not pain her by applying the crucial test, and finally detecting her?

289.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Nonsense, Socrates.

290.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Why?
because I said that we had better not pain pleasure, which is an impossibility?

291.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, and more than that, because you do not seem to be aware that none of us will let you go home until you have finished the argument.

292.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Heavens!
Protarchus, that will be a tedious business, and just at present not at all an easy one.
For in going to war in the cause of mind, who is aspiring to the second prize, I ought to have weapons of another make from those which I used before; some, however, of the old ones may do again.
And must I then finish the argument?

293.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Of course you must.

294.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let us be very careful in laying the foundation.

295.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What do you mean?

296.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let us divide all existing things into two, or rather, if you do not object, into three classes.

297.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Upon what principle would you make the division?

298.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let us take some of our newly-found notions.

299.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Which of them?

300.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Were we not saying that God revealed a finite element of existence, and also an infinite?

301.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

302.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let us assume these two principles, and also a third, which is compounded out of them; but I fear that I am ridiculously clumsy at these processes of division and enumeration.

303.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What do you mean, my good friend?

304.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I say that a fourth class is still wanted.

305.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What will that be?

306.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Find the cause of the third or compound, and add this as a fourth class to the three others.

307.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: And would you like to have a fifth class or cause of resolution as well as a cause of composition?

308.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Not, I think, at present; but if I want a fifth at some future time you shall allow me to have it.

309.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

310.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let us begin with the first three; and as we find two out of the three greatly divided and dispersed, let us endeavour to reunite them, and see how in each of them there is a one and many.

311.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: If you would explain to me a little more about them, perhaps I might be able to follow you.

312.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, the two classes are the same which I mentioned before, one the finite, and the other the infinite; I will first show that the infinite is in a certain sense many, and the finite may be hereafter discussed.

313.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I agree.

314.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now consider well; for the question to which I invite your attention is difficult and controverted.
When you speak of hotter and colder, can you conceive any limit in those qualities?
Does not the more and less, which dwells in their very nature, prevent their having any end?
for if they had an end, the more and less would themselves have an end.

315.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That is most true.

316.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Ever, as we say, into the hotter and the colder there enters a more and a less.

317.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

318.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then, says the argument, there is never any end of them, and being endless they must also be infinite.

319.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, Socrates, that is exceedingly true.

320.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Yes, my dear Protarchus, and your answer reminds me that such an expression as 'exceedingly,' which you have just uttered, and also the term 'gently,' have the same significance as more or less; for whenever they occur they do not allow of the existence of quantity—they are always introducing degrees into actions, instituting a comparison of a more or a less excessive or a more or a less gentle, and at each creation of more or less, quantity disappears.

For, as I was just now saying, if quantity and measure did not disappear, but were allowed to intrude in the sphere of more and less and the other comparatives, these last would be driven out of their own domain.

When definite quantity is once admitted, there can be no longer a 'hotter' or a 'colder' (for these are always progressing, and are never in one stay); but definite quantity is at rest, and has ceased to progress.
Which proves that comparatives, such as the hotter and the colder, are to be ranked in the class of the infinite.

321.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Your remark certainly has the look of truth, Socrates; but these subjects, as you were saying, are difficult to follow at first.
I think however, that if I could hear the argument repeated by you once or twice, there would be a substantial agreement between us.

322.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Yes, and I will try to meet your wish; but, as I would rather not waste time in the enumeration of endless particulars, let me know whether I may not assume as a note of the infinite—

323.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What?

324.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I want to know whether such things as appear to us to admit of more or less, or are denoted by the words 'exceedingly,' 'gently,' 'extremely,' and the like, may not be referred to the class of the infinite, which is their unity, for, as was asserted in the previous argument, all things that were divided and dispersed should be brought together, and have the mark or seal of some one nature, if possible, set upon them—do you remember?

325.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

326.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And all things which do not admit of more or less, but admit their opposites, that is to say, first of all, equality, and the equal, or again, the double, or any other ratio of number and measure—all these may, I think, be rightly reckoned by us in the class of the limited or finite; what do you say?

327.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Excellent, Socrates.

328.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now what nature shall we ascribe to the third or compound kind?

329.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: You, I think, will have to tell me that.

330.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Rather God will tell you, if there be any God who will listen to my prayers.

331.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Offer up a prayer, then, and think.

332.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I am thinking, Protarchus, and I believe that some God has befriended us.

333.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What do you mean, and what proof have you to offer of what you are saying?

334.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I will tell you, and do you listen to my words.

335.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Proceed.

336.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Were we not speaking just now of hotter and colder?

337.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

338.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Add to them drier, wetter, more, less, swifter, slower, greater, smaller, and all that in the preceding argument we placed under the unity of more and less.

339.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: In the class of the infinite, you mean?

340.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Yes; and now mingle this with the other.

341.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What is the other.

342.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The class of the finite which we ought to have brought together as we did the infinite; but, perhaps, it will come to the same thing if we do so now;—when the two are combined, a third will appear.

343.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What do you mean by the class of the finite?

344.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The class of the equal and the double, and any class which puts an end to difference and opposition, and by introducing number creates harmony and proportion among the different elements.

345.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I understand; you seem to me to mean that the various opposites, when you mingle with them the class of the finite, takes certain forms.

346.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Yes, that is my meaning.

347.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Proceed.

348.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Does not the right participation in the finite give health—in disease, for instance?

349.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

350.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And whereas the high and low, the swift and the slow are infinite or unlimited, does not the addition of the principles aforesaid introduce a limit, and perfect the whole frame of music?

351.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, certainly.

352.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Or, again, when cold and heat prevail, does not the introduction of them take away excess and indefiniteness, and infuse moderation and harmony?

353.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

354.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And from a like admixture of the finite and infinite come the seasons, and all the delights of life?

355.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Most true.

356.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I omit ten thousand other things, such as beauty and health and strength, and the many beauties and high perfections of the soul:  O my beautiful Philebus, the goddess, methinks, seeing the universal wantonness and wickedness of all things, and that there was in them no limit to pleasures and self-indulgence, devised the limit of law and order, whereby, as you say, Philebus, she torments, or as I maintain, delivers the soul.—What think you, Protarchus?

357.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Her ways are much to my mind, Socrates.

358.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: You will observe that I have spoken of three classes?

359.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, I think that I understand you:  you mean to say that the infinite is one class, and that the finite is a second class of existences; but what you would make the third I am not so certain.

360.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: That is because the amazing variety of the third class is too much for you, my dear friend; but there was not this difficulty with the infinite, which also comprehended many classes, for all of them were sealed with the note of more and less, and therefore appeared one.

361.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

362.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the finite or limit had not many divisions, and we readily acknowledged it to be by nature one?

363.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

364.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Yes, indeed; and when I speak of the third class, understand me to mean any offspring of these, being a birth into true being, effected by the measure which the limit introduces.

365.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I understand.

366.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Still there was, as we said, a fourth class to be investigated, and you must assist in the investigation; for does not everything which comes into being, of necessity come into being through a cause?

367.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, certainly; for how can there be anything which has no cause?

368.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And is not the agent the same as the cause in all except name; the agent and the cause may be rightly called one?

369.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

370.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the same may be said of the patient, or effect; we shall find that they too differ, as I was saying, only in name—shall we not?

371.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: We shall.

372.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The agent or cause always naturally leads, and the patient or effect naturally follows it?

373.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

374.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then the cause and what is subordinate to it in generation are not the same, but different?

375.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

376.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Did not the things which were generated, and the things out of which they were generated, furnish all the three classes?

377.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

378.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the creator or cause of them has been satisfactorily proven to be distinct from them,—and may therefore be called a fourth principle?

379.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: So let us call it.

380.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Quite right; but now, having distinguished the four, I think that we had better refresh our memories by recapitulating each of them in order.

381.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: By all means.

382.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then the first I will call the infinite or unlimited, and the second the finite or limited; then follows the third, an essence compound and generated; and I do not think that I shall be far wrong in speaking of the cause of mixture and generation as the fourth.

383.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly not.

384.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now what is the next question, and how came we hither?
Were we not enquiring whether the second place belonged to pleasure or wisdom?

385.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: We were.

386.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now, having determined these points, shall we not be better able to decide about the first and second place, which was the original subject of dispute?

387.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I dare say.

388.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: We said, if you remember, that the mixed life of pleasure and wisdom was the conqueror—did we not?

389.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

390.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And we see what is the place and nature of this life and to what class it is to be assigned?

391.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Beyond a doubt.

392.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: This is evidently comprehended in the third or mixed class; which is not composed of any two particular ingredients, but of all the elements of infinity, bound down by the finite, and may therefore be truly said to comprehend the conqueror life.

393.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Most true.

394.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And what shall we say, Philebus, of your life which is all sweetness; and in which of the aforesaid classes is that to be placed?
Perhaps you will allow me to ask you a question before you answer?

395.speaker: PHILEBUS
sentences: Let me hear.

396.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Have pleasure and pain a limit, or do they belong to the class which admits of more and less?

397.speaker: PHILEBUS
sentences: They belong to the class which admits of more, Socrates; for pleasure would not be perfectly good if she were not infinite in quantity and degree.

398.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Nor would pain, Philebus, be perfectly evil.
And therefore the infinite cannot be that element which imparts to pleasure some degree of good.

But now—admitting, if you like, that pleasure is of the nature of the infinite—in which of the aforesaid classes, O Protarchus and Philebus, can we without irreverence place wisdom and knowledge and mind?
And let us be careful, for I think that the danger will be very serious if we err on this point.

399.speaker: PHILEBUS
sentences: You magnify, Socrates, the importance of your favourite god.

400.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And you, my friend, are also magnifying your favourite goddess; but still I must beg you to answer the question.

401.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Socrates is quite right, Philebus, and we must submit to him.

402.speaker: PHILEBUS
sentences: And did not you, Protarchus, propose to answer in my place?

403.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly I did; but I am now in a great strait, and I must entreat you, Socrates, to be our spokesman, and then we shall not say anything wrong or disrespectful of your favourite.

404.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I must obey you, Protarchus; nor is the task which you impose a difficult one; but did I really, as Philebus implies, disconcert you with my playful solemnity, when I asked the question to what class mind and knowledge belong?

405.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: You did, indeed, Socrates.

406.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Yet the answer is easy, since all philosophers assert with one voice that mind is the king of heaven and earth—in reality they are magnifying themselves.
And perhaps they are right.
But still I should like to consider the class of mind, if you do not object, a little more fully.

407.speaker: PHILEBUS
sentences: Take your own course, Socrates, and never mind length; we shall not tire of you.

408.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Very good; let us begin then, Protarchus, by asking a question.

409.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What question?

410.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Whether all this which they call the universe is left to the guidance of unreason and chance medley, or, on the contrary, as our fathers have declared, ordered and governed by a marvellous intelligence and wisdom.

411.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Wide asunder are the two assertions, illustrious Socrates, for that which you were just now saying to me appears to be blasphemy; but the other assertion, that mind orders all things, is worthy of the aspect of the world, and of the sun, and of the moon, and of the stars and of the whole circle of the heavens; and never will I say or think otherwise.

412.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Shall we then agree with them of old time in maintaining this doctrine,—not merely reasserting the notions of others, without risk to ourselves,—but shall we share in the danger, and take our part of the reproach which will await us, when an ingenious individual declares that all is disorder?

413.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That would certainly be my wish.

414.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then now please to consider the next stage of the argument.

415.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Let me hear.

416.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: We see that the elements which enter into the nature of the bodies of all animals, fire, water, air, and, as the storm-tossed sailor cries, 'land' (i.e., earth), reappear in the constitution of the world.

417.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: The proverb may be applied to us; for truly the storm gathers over us, and we are at our wit's end.

418.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: There is something to be remarked about each of these elements.

419.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What is it?

420.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Only a small fraction of any one of them exists in us, and that of a mean sort, and not in any way pure, or having any power worthy of its nature.
One instance will prove this of all of them; there is fire within us, and in the universe.

421.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

422.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And is not our fire small and weak and mean?
But the fire in the universe is wonderful in quantity and beauty, and in every power that fire has.

423.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Most true.

424.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And is the fire in the universe nourished and generated and ruled by the fire in us, or is the fire in you and me, and in other animals, dependent on the universal fire?

425.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That is a question which does not deserve an answer.

426.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Right; and you would say the same, if I am not mistaken, of the earth which is in animals and the earth which is in the universe, and you would give a similar reply about all the other elements?

427.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Why, how could any man who gave any other be deemed in his senses?

428.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I do not think that he could—but now go on to the next step.
When we saw those elements of which we have been speaking gathered up in one, did we not call them a body?

429.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: We did.

430.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the same may be said of the cosmos, which for the same reason may be considered to be a body, because made up of the same elements.

431.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

432.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But is our body nourished wholly by this body, or is this body nourished by our body, thence deriving and having the qualities of which we were just now speaking?

433.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That again, Socrates, is a question which does not deserve to be asked.

434.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, tell me, is this question worth asking?

435.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What question?

436.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: May our body be said to have a soul?

437.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Clearly.

438.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And whence comes that soul, my dear Protarchus, unless the body of the universe, which contains elements like those in our bodies but in every way fairer, had also a soul?
Can there be another source?

439.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Clearly, Socrates, that is the only source.

440.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Why, yes, Protarchus; for surely we cannot imagine that of the four classes, the finite, the infinite, the composition of the two, and the cause, the fourth, which enters into all things, giving to our bodies souls, and the art of self-management, and of healing disease, and operating in other ways to heal and organize, having too all the attributes of wisdom;—we cannot, I say, imagine that whereas the self-same elements exist, both in the entire heaven and in great provinces of the heaven, only fairer and purer, this last should not also in that higher sphere have designed the noblest and fairest things?

441.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Such a supposition is quite unreasonable.

442.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then if this be denied, should we not be wise in adopting the other view and maintaining that there is in the universe a mighty infinite and an adequate limit, of which we have often spoken, as well as a presiding cause of no mean power, which orders and arranges years and seasons and months, and may be justly called wisdom and mind?

443.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Most justly.

444.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And wisdom and mind cannot exist without soul?

445.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly not.

446.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And in the divine nature of Zeus would you not say that there is the soul and mind of a king, because there is in him the power of the cause?
And other gods have other attributes, by which they are pleased to be called.

447.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

448.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Do not then suppose that these words are rashly spoken by us, O Protarchus, for they are in harmony with the testimony of those who said of old time that mind rules the universe.

449.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

450.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And they furnish an answer to my enquiry; for they imply that mind is the parent of that class of the four which we called the cause of all; and I think that you now have my answer.

451.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I have indeed, and yet I did not observe that you had answered.

452.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: A jest is sometimes refreshing, Protarchus, when it interrupts earnest.

453.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

454.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I think, friend, that we have now pretty clearly set forth the class to which mind belongs and what is the power of mind.

455.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

456.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the class to which pleasure belongs has also been long ago discovered?

457.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

458.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And let us remember, too, of both of them, (1) that mind was akin to the cause and of this family; and (2) that pleasure is infinite and belongs to the class which neither has, nor ever will have in itself, a beginning, middle, or end of its own.

459.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I shall be sure to remember.

460.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: We must next examine what is their place and under what conditions they are generated.
And we will begin with pleasure, since her class was first examined; and yet pleasure cannot be rightly tested apart from pain.

461.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: If this is the road, let us take it.

462.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I wonder whether you would agree with me about the origin of pleasure and pain.

463.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What do you mean?

464.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I mean to say that their natural seat is in the mixed class.

465.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: And would you tell me again, sweet Socrates, which of the aforesaid classes is the mixed one?

466.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I will, my fine fellow, to the best of my ability.

467.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very good.

468.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let us then understand the mixed class to be that which we placed third in the list of four.

469.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That which followed the infinite and the finite; and in which you ranked health, and, if I am not mistaken, harmony.

470.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Capital; and now will you please to give me your best attention?

471.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Proceed; I am attending.

472.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I say that when the harmony in animals is dissolved, there is also a dissolution of nature and a generation of pain.

473.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That is very probable.

474.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the restoration of harmony and return to nature is the source of pleasure, if I may be allowed to speak in the fewest and shortest words about matters of the greatest moment.

475.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I believe that you are right, Socrates; but will you try to be a little plainer?

476.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Do not obvious and every-day phenomena furnish the simplest illustration?

477.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What phenomena do you mean?

478.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Hunger, for example, is a dissolution and a pain.

479.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

480.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Whereas eating is a replenishment and a pleasure?

481.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

482.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Thirst again is a destruction and a pain, but the effect of moisture replenishing the dry place is a pleasure:  once more, the unnatural separation and dissolution caused by heat is painful, and the natural restoration and refrigeration is pleasant.

483.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

484.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the unnatural freezing of the moisture in an animal is pain, and the natural process of resolution and return of the elements to their original state is pleasure.

And would not the general proposition seem to you to hold, that the destroying of the natural union of the finite and infinite, which, as I was observing before, make up the class of living beings, is pain, and that the process of return of all things to their own nature is pleasure?

485.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Granted; what you say has a general truth.

486.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Here then is one kind of pleasures and pains originating severally in the two processes which we have described?

487.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Good.

488.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let us next assume that in the soul herself there is an antecedent hope of pleasure which is sweet and refreshing, and an expectation of pain, fearful and anxious.

489.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes; this is another class of pleasures and pains, which is of the soul only, apart from the body, and is produced by expectation.

490.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Right; for in the analysis of these, pure, as I suppose them to be, the pleasures being unalloyed with pain and the pains with pleasure, methinks that we shall see clearly whether the whole class of pleasure is to be desired, or whether this quality of entire desirableness is not rather to be attributed to another of the classes which have been mentioned; and whether pleasure and pain, like heat and cold, and other things of the same kind, are not sometimes to be desired and sometimes not to be desired, as being not in themselves good, but only sometimes and in some instances admitting of the nature of good.

491.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: You say most truly that this is the track which the investigation should pursue.

492.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, then, assuming that pain ensues on the dissolution, and pleasure on the restoration of the harmony, let us now ask what will be the condition of animated beings who are neither in process of restoration nor of dissolution.
And mind what you say:  I ask whether any animal who is in that condition can possibly have any feeling of pleasure or pain, great or small?

493.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly not.

494.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then here we have a third state, over and above that of pleasure and of pain?

495.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

496.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And do not forget that there is such a state; it will make a great difference in our judgment of pleasure, whether we remember this or not.
And I should like to say a few words about it.

497.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What have you to say?

498.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Why, you know that if a man chooses the life of wisdom, there is no reason why he should not live in this neutral state.

499.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: You mean that he may live neither rejoicing nor sorrowing?

500.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Yes; and if I remember rightly, when the lives were compared, no degree of pleasure, whether great or small, was thought to be necessary to him who chose the life of thought and wisdom.

501.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, certainly, we said so.

502.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then he will live without pleasure; and who knows whether this may not be the most divine of all lives?

503.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: If so, the gods, at any rate, cannot be supposed to have either joy or sorrow.

504.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Certainly not—there would be a great impropriety in the assumption of either alternative.

But whether the gods are or are not indifferent to pleasure is a point which may be considered hereafter if in any way relevant to the argument, and whatever is the conclusion we will place it to the account of mind in her contest for the second place, should she have to resign the first.

505.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Just so.

506.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The other class of pleasures, which as we were saying is purely mental, is entirely derived from memory.

507.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What do you mean?

508.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I must first of all analyze memory, or rather perception which is prior to memory, if the subject of our discussion is ever to be properly cleared up.

509.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How will you proceed?

510.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let us imagine affections of the body which are extinguished before they reach the soul, and leave her unaffected; and again, other affections which vibrate through both soul and body, and impart a shock to both and to each of them.

511.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Granted.

512.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the soul may be truly said to be oblivious of the first but not of the second?

513.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Quite true.

514.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: When I say oblivious, do not suppose that I mean forgetfulness in a literal sense; for forgetfulness is the exit of memory, which in this case has not yet entered; and to speak of the loss of that which is not yet in existence, and never has been, is a contradiction; do you see?

515.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

516.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then just be so good as to change the terms.

517.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How shall I change them?

518.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Instead of the oblivion of the soul, when you are describing the state in which she is unaffected by the shocks of the body, say unconsciousness.

519.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I see.

520.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the union or communion of soul and body in one feeling and motion would be properly called consciousness?

521.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Most true.

522.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then now we know the meaning of the word?

523.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

524.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And memory may, I think, be rightly described as the preservation of consciousness?

525.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Right.

526.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But do we not distinguish memory from recollection?

527.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I think so.

528.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And do we not mean by recollection the power which the soul has of recovering, when by herself, some feeling which she experienced when in company with the body?

529.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

530.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And when she recovers of herself the lost recollection of some consciousness or knowledge, the recovery is termed recollection and reminiscence?

531.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

532.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: There is a reason why I say all this.

533.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What is it?

534.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I want to attain the plainest possible notion of pleasure and desire, as they exist in the mind only, apart from the body; and the previous analysis helps to show the nature of both.

535.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Then now, Socrates, let us proceed to the next point.

536.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: There are certainly many things to be considered in discussing the generation and whole complexion of pleasure.
At the outset we must determine the nature and seat of desire.

537.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Ay; let us enquire into that, for we shall lose nothing.

538.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Nay, Protarchus, we shall surely lose the puzzle if we find the answer.

539.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: A fair retort; but let us proceed.

540.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Did we not place hunger, thirst, and the like, in the class of desires?

541.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

542.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And yet they are very different; what common nature have we in view when we call them by a single name?

543.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: By heavens, Socrates, that is a question which is not easily answered; but it must be answered.

544.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then let us go back to our examples.

545.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Where shall we begin?

546.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Do we mean anything when we say 'a man thirsts'?

547.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

548.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: We mean to say that he 'is empty'?

549.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Of course.

550.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And is not thirst desire?

551.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, of drink.

552.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Would you say of drink, or of replenishment with drink?

553.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I should say, of replenishment with drink.

554.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then he who is empty desires, as would appear, the opposite of what he experiences; for he is empty and desires to be full?

555.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Clearly so.

556.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But how can a man who is empty for the first time, attain either by perception or memory to any apprehension of replenishment, of which he has no present or past experience?

557.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Impossible.

558.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And yet he who desires, surely desires something?

559.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Of course.

560.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: He does not desire that which he experiences, for he experiences thirst, and thirst is emptiness; but he desires replenishment?

561.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

562.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then there must be something in the thirsty man which in some way apprehends replenishment?

563.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: There must.

564.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And that cannot be the body, for the body is supposed to be emptied?

565.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

566.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The only remaining alternative is that the soul apprehends the replenishment by the help of memory; as is obvious, for what other way can there be?

567.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I cannot imagine any other.

568.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But do you see the consequence?

569.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What is it?

570.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: That there is no such thing as desire of the body.

571.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Why so?

572.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Why, because the argument shows that the endeavour of every animal is to the reverse of his bodily state.

573.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

574.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the impulse which leads him to the opposite of what he is experiencing proves that he has a memory of the opposite state.

575.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

576.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the argument, having proved that memory attracts us towards the objects of desire, proves also that the impulses and the desires and the moving principle in every living being have their origin in the soul.

577.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Most true.

578.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The argument will not allow that our body either hungers or thirsts or has any similar experience.

579.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Quite right.

580.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let me make a further observation; the argument appears to me to imply that there is a kind of life which consists in these affections.

581.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Of what affections, and of what kind of life, are you speaking?

582.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I am speaking of being emptied and replenished, and of all that relates to the preservation and destruction of living beings, as well as of the pain which is felt in one of these states and of the pleasure which succeeds to it.

583.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

584.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And what would you say of the intermediate state?

585.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What do you mean by 'intermediate'?

586.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I mean when a person is in actual suffering and yet remembers past pleasures which, if they would only return, would relieve him; but as yet he has them not.
May we not say of him, that he is in an intermediate state?

587.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

588.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Would you say that he was wholly pained or wholly pleased?

589.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Nay, I should say that he has two pains; in his body there is the actual experience of pain, and in his soul longing and expectation.

590.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: What do you mean, Protarchus, by the two pains?
May not a man who is empty have at one time a sure hope of being filled, and at other times be quite in despair?

591.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

592.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And has he not the pleasure of memory when he is hoping to be filled, and yet in that he is empty is he not at the same time in pain?

593.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

594.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then man and the other animals have at the same time both pleasure and pain?

595.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I suppose so.

596.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But when a man is empty and has no hope of being filled, there will be the double experience of pain.
You observed this and inferred that the double experience was the single case possible.

597.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Quite true, Socrates.

598.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Shall the enquiry into these states of feeling be made the occasion of raising a question?

599.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What question?

600.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Whether we ought to say that the pleasures and pains of which we are speaking are true or false?
or some true and some false?

601.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: But how, Socrates, can there be false pleasures and pains?

602.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And how, Protarchus, can there be true and false fears, or true and false expectations, or true and false opinions?

603.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I grant that opinions may be true or false, but not pleasures.

604.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: What do you mean?
I am afraid that we are raising a very serious enquiry.

605.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: There I agree.

606.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And yet, my boy, for you are one of Philebus' boys, the point to be considered, is, whether the enquiry is relevant to the argument.

607.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Surely.

608.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: No tedious and irrelevant discussion can be allowed; what is said should be pertinent.

609.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Right.

610.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I am always wondering at the question which has now been raised.

611.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How so?

612.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Do you deny that some pleasures are false, and others true?

613.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: To be sure I do.

614.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Would you say that no one ever seemed to rejoice and yet did not rejoice, or seemed to feel pain and yet did not feel pain, sleeping or waking, mad or lunatic?

615.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: So we have always held, Socrates.

616.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But were you right?
Shall we enquire into the truth of your opinion?

617.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I think that we should.

618.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let us then put into more precise terms the question which has arisen about pleasure and opinion.
Is there such a thing as opinion?

619.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

620.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And such a thing as pleasure?

621.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

622.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And an opinion must be of something?

623.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

624.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And a man must be pleased by something?

625.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Quite correct.

626.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And whether the opinion be right or wrong, makes no difference; it will still be an opinion?

627.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

628.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And he who is pleased, whether he is rightly pleased or not, will always have a real feeling of pleasure?

629.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes; that is also quite true.

630.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then, how can opinion be both true and false, and pleasure true only, although pleasure and opinion are both equally real?

631.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes; that is the question.

632.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: You mean that opinion admits of truth and falsehood, and hence becomes not merely opinion, but opinion of a certain quality; and this is what you think should be examined?

633.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

634.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And further, even if we admit the existence of qualities in other objects, may not pleasure and pain be simple and devoid of quality?

635.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Clearly.

636.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But there is no difficulty in seeing that pleasure and pain as well as opinion have qualities, for they are great or small, and have various degrees of intensity; as was indeed said long ago by us.

637.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Quite true.

638.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if badness attaches to any of them, Protarchus, then we should speak of a bad opinion or of a bad pleasure?

639.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Quite true, Socrates.

640.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if rightness attaches to any of them, should we not speak of a right opinion or right pleasure; and in like manner of the reverse of rightness?

641.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

642.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if the thing opined be erroneous, might we not say that the opinion, being erroneous, is not right or rightly opined?

643.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

644.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if we see a pleasure or pain which errs in respect of its object, shall we call that right or good, or by any honourable name?

645.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Not if the pleasure is mistaken; how could we?

646.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And surely pleasure often appears to accompany an opinion which is not true, but false?

647.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly it does; and in that case, Socrates, as we were saying, the opinion is false, but no one could call the actual pleasure false.

648.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: How eagerly, Protarchus, do you rush to the defence of pleasure!

649.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Nay, Socrates, I only repeat what I hear.

650.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And is there no difference, my friend, between that pleasure which is associated with right opinion and knowledge, and that which is often found in all of us associated with falsehood and ignorance?

651.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: There must be a very great difference, between them.

652.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then, now let us proceed to contemplate this difference.

653.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Lead, and I will follow.

654.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, then, my view is—

655.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What is it?

656.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: We agree—do we not?—that there is such a thing as false, and also such a thing as true opinion?

657.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

658.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And pleasure and pain, as I was just now saying, are often consequent upon these—upon true and false opinion, I mean.

659.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

660.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And do not opinion and the endeavour to form an opinion always spring from memory and perception?

661.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

662.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Might we imagine the process to be something of this nature?

663.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Of what nature?

664.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: An object may be often seen at a distance not very clearly, and the seer may want to determine what it is which he sees.

665.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very likely.

666.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Soon he begins to interrogate himself.

667.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: In what manner?

668.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: He asks himself—'What is that which appears to be standing by the rock under the tree?'
This is the question which he may be supposed to put to himself when he sees such an appearance.

669.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

670.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: To which he may guess the right answer, saying as if in a whisper to himself—'It is a man.'

671.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very good.

672.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Or again, he may be misled, and then he will say—'No, it is a figure made by the shepherds.'

673.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

674.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if he has a companion, he repeats his thought to him in articulate sounds, and what was before an opinion, has now become a proposition.

675.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

676.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But if he be walking alone when these thoughts occur to him, he may not unfrequently keep them in his mind for a considerable time.

677.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

678.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, now, I wonder whether you would agree in my explanation of this phenomenon.

679.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What is your explanation?

680.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I think that the soul at such times is like a book.

681.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How so?

682.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Memory and perception meet, and they and their attendant feelings seem to almost to write down words in the soul, and when the inscribing feeling writes truly, then true opinion and true propositions which are the expressions of opinion come into our souls—but when the scribe within us writes falsely, the result is false.

683.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I quite assent and agree to your statement.

684.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I must bespeak your favour also for another artist, who is busy at the same time in the chambers of the soul.

685.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Who is he?

686.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The painter, who, after the scribe has done his work, draws images in the soul of the things which he has described.

687.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: But when and how does he do this?

688.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: When a man, besides receiving from sight or some other sense certain opinions or statements, sees in his mind the images of the subjects of them;—is not this a very common mental phenomenon?

689.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

690.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the images answering to true opinions and words are true, and to false opinions and words false; are they not?

691.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: They are.

692.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: If we are right so far, there arises a further question.

693.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What is it?

694.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Whether we experience the feeling of which I am speaking only in relation to the present and the past, or in relation to the future also?

695.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I should say in relation to all times alike.

696.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Have not purely mental pleasures and pains been described already as in some cases anticipations of the bodily ones; from which we may infer that anticipatory pleasures and pains have to do with the future?

697.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Most true.

698.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And do all those writings and paintings which, as we were saying a little while ago, are produced in us, relate to the past and present only, and not to the future?

699.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: To the future, very much.

700.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: When you say, 'Very much,' you mean to imply that all these representations are hopes about the future, and that mankind are filled with hopes in every stage of existence?

701.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Exactly.

702.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Answer me another question.

703.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What question?

704.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: A just and pious and good man is the friend of the gods; is he not?

705.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly he is.

706.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the unjust and utterly bad man is the reverse?

707.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

708.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And all men, as we were saying just now, are always filled with hopes?

709.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

710.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And these hopes, as they are termed, are propositions which exist in the minds of each of us?

711.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

712.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the fancies of hope are also pictured in us; a man may often have a vision of a heap of gold, and pleasures ensuing, and in the picture there may be a likeness of himself mightily rejoicing over his good fortune.

713.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

714.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And may we not say that the good, being friends of the gods, have generally true pictures presented to them, and the bad false pictures?

715.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

716.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The bad, too, have pleasures painted in their fancy as well as the good; but I presume that they are false pleasures.

717.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: They are.

718.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The bad then commonly delight in false pleasures, and the good in true pleasures?

719.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Doubtless.

720.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then upon this view there are false pleasures in the souls of men which are a ludicrous imitation of the true, and there are pains of a similar character?

721.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: There are.

722.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And did we not allow that a man who had an opinion at all had a real opinion, but often about things which had no existence either in the past, present, or future?

723.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Quite true.

724.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And this was the source of false opinion and opining; am I not right?

725.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

726.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And must we not attribute to pleasure and pain a similar real but illusory character?

727.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How do you mean?

728.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I mean to say that a man must be admitted to have real pleasure who is pleased with anything or anyhow; and he may be pleased about things which neither have nor have ever had any real existence, and, more often than not, are never likely to exist.

729.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, Socrates, that again is undeniable.

730.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And may not the same be said about fear and anger and the like; are they not often false?

731.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Quite so.

732.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And can opinions be good or bad except in as far as they are true or false?

733.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: In no other way.

734.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Nor can pleasures be conceived to be bad except in so far as they are false.

735.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Nay, Socrates, that is the very opposite of truth; for no one would call pleasures and pains bad because they are false, but by reason of some other great corruption to which they are liable.

736.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, of pleasures which are corrupt and caused by corruption we will hereafter speak, if we care to continue the enquiry; for the present I would rather show by another argument that there are many false pleasures existing or coming into existence in us, because this may assist our final decision.

737.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true; that is to say, if there are such pleasures.

738.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I think that there are, Protarchus; but this is an opinion which should be well assured, and not rest upon a mere assertion.

739.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very good.

740.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then now, like wrestlers, let us approach and grasp this new argument.

741.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Proceed.

742.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: We were maintaining a little while since, that when desires, as they are termed, exist in us, then the body has separate feelings apart from the soul—do you remember?

743.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, I remember that you said so.

744.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the soul was supposed to desire the opposite of the bodily state, while the body was the source of any pleasure or pain which was experienced.

745.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

746.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then now you may infer what happens in such cases.

747.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What am I to infer?

748.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: That in such cases pleasures and pains come simultaneously; and there is a juxtaposition of the opposite sensations which correspond to them, as has been already shown.

749.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Clearly.

750.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And there is another point to which we have agreed.

751.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What is it?

752.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: That pleasure and pain both admit of more and less, and that they are of the class of infinites.

753.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly, we said so.

754.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But how can we rightly judge of them?

755.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How can we?

756.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Is it our intention to judge of their comparative importance and intensity, measuring pleasure against pain, and pain against pain, and pleasure against pleasure?

757.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, such is our intention, and we shall judge of them accordingly.

758.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, take the case of sight.
Does not the nearness or distance of magnitudes obscure their true proportions, and make us opine falsely; and do we not find the same illusion happening in the case of pleasures and pains?

759.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, Socrates, and in a degree far greater.

760.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then what we are now saying is the opposite of what we were saying before.

761.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What was that?

762.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then the opinions were true and false, and infected the pleasures and pains with their own falsity.

763.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

764.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But now it is the pleasures which are said to be true and false because they are seen at various distances, and subjected to comparison; the pleasures appear to be greater and more vehement when placed side by side with the pains, and the pains when placed side by side with the pleasures.

765.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly, and for the reason which you mention.

766.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And suppose you part off from pleasures and pains the element which makes them appear to be greater or less than they really are:  you will acknowledge that this element is illusory, and you will never say that the corresponding excess or defect of pleasure or pain is real or true.

767.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly not.

768.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Next let us see whether in another direction we may not find pleasures and pains existing and appearing in living beings, which are still more false than these.

769.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What are they, and how shall we find them?

770.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: If I am not mistaken, I have often repeated that pains and aches and suffering and uneasiness of all sorts arise out of a corruption of nature caused by concretions, and dissolutions, and repletions, and evacuations, and also by growth and decay?

771.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, that has been often said.

772.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And we have also agreed that the restoration of the natural state is pleasure?

773.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Right.

774.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But now let us suppose an interval of time at which the body experiences none of these changes.

775.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: When can that be, Socrates?

776.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Your question, Protarchus, does not help the argument.

777.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Why not, Socrates?

778.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Because it does not prevent me from repeating mine.

779.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: And what was that?

780.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Why, Protarchus, admitting that there is no such interval, I may ask what would be the necessary consequence if there were?

781.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: You mean, what would happen if the body were not changed either for good or bad?

782.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Yes.

783.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Why then, Socrates, I should suppose that there would be neither pleasure nor pain.

784.speaker: SOCRATES
