sentences: Very good; but still, if I am not mistaken, you do assert that we must always be experiencing one of them; that is what the wise tell us; for, say they, all things are ever flowing up and down.

785.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, and their words are of no mean authority.

786.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Of course, for they are no mean authorities themselves; and I should like to avoid the brunt of their argument.
Shall I tell you how I mean to escape from them?
And you shall be the partner of my flight.

787.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How?

788.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: To them we will say:  'Good; but are we, or living things in general, always conscious of what happens to us—for example, of our growth, or the like?
Are we not, on the contrary, almost wholly unconscious of this and similar phenomena?'
You must answer for them.

789.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: The latter alternative is the true one.

790.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then we were not right in saying, just now, that motions going up and down cause pleasures and pains?

791.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

792.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: A better and more unexceptionable way of speaking will be—

793.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What?

794.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: If we say that the great changes produce pleasures and pains, but that the moderate and lesser ones do neither.

795.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That, Socrates, is the more correct mode of speaking.

796.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But if this be true, the life to which I was just now referring again appears.

797.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What life?

798.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The life which we affirmed to be devoid either of pain or of joy.

799.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

800.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: We may assume then that there are three lives, one pleasant, one painful, and the third which is neither; what say you?

801.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I should say as you do that there are three of them.

802.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But if so, the negation of pain will not be the same with pleasure.

803.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly not.

804.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then when you hear a person saying, that always to live without pain is the pleasantest of all things, what would you understand him to mean by that statement?

805.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I think that by pleasure he must mean the negative of pain.

806.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let us take any three things; or suppose that we embellish a little and call the first gold, the second silver, and there shall be a third which is neither.

807.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very good.

808.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Now, can that which is neither be either gold or silver?

809.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Impossible.

810.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: No more can that neutral or middle life be rightly or reasonably spoken or thought of as pleasant or painful.

811.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly not.

812.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And yet, my friend, there are, as we know, persons who say and think so.

813.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

814.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And do they think that they have pleasure when they are free from pain?

815.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: They say so.

816.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And they must think or they would not say that they have pleasure.

817.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I suppose not.

818.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And yet if pleasure and the negation of pain are of distinct natures, they are wrong.

819.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: But they are undoubtedly of distinct natures.

820.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then shall we take the view that they are three, as we were just now saying, or that they are two only—the one being a state of pain, which is an evil, and the other a cessation of pain, which is of itself a good, and is called pleasant?

821.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: But why, Socrates, do we ask the question at all?
I do not see the reason.

822.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: You, Protarchus, have clearly never heard of certain enemies of our friend Philebus.

823.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: And who may they be?

824.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Certain persons who are reputed to be masters in natural philosophy, who deny the very existence of pleasure.

825.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Indeed!

826.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: They say that what the school of Philebus calls pleasures are all of them only avoidances of pain.

827.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: And would you, Socrates, have us agree with them?

828.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Why, no, I would rather use them as a sort of diviners, who divine the truth, not by rules of art, but by an instinctive repugnance and extreme detestation which a noble nature has of the power of pleasure, in which they think that there is nothing sound, and her seductive influence is declared by them to be witchcraft, and not pleasure.
This is the use which you may make of them.
And when you have considered the various grounds of their dislike, you shall hear from me what I deem to be true pleasures.
Having thus examined the nature of pleasure from both points of view, we will bring her up for judgment.

829.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Well said.

830.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then let us enter into an alliance with these philosophers and follow in the track of their dislike.

I imagine that they would say something of this sort; they would begin at the beginning, and ask whether, if we wanted to know the nature of any quality, such as hardness, we should be more likely to discover it by looking at the hardest things, rather than at the least hard?
You, Protarchus, shall answer these severe gentlemen as you answer me.

831.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: By all means, and I reply to them, that you should look at the greatest instances.

832.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then if we want to see the true nature of pleasures as a class, we should not look at the most diluted pleasures, but at the most extreme and most vehement?

833.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: In that every one will agree.

834.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the obvious instances of the greatest pleasures, as we have often said, are the pleasures of the body?

835.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

836.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And are they felt by us to be or become greater, when we are sick or when we are in health?
And here we must be careful in our answer, or we shall come to grief.

837.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How will that be?

838.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Why, because we might be tempted to answer, 'When we are in health.'

839.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, that is the natural answer.

840.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, but are not those pleasures the greatest of which mankind have the greatest desires?

841.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

842.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And do not people who are in a fever, or any similar illness, feel cold or thirst or other bodily affections more intensely?
Am I not right in saying that they have a deeper want and greater pleasure in the satisfaction of their want?

843.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That is obvious as soon as it is said.

844.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, then, shall we not be right in saying, that if a person would wish to see the greatest pleasures he ought to go and look, not at health, but at disease?

And here you must distinguish: —do not imagine that I mean to ask whether those who are very ill have more pleasures than those who are well, but understand that I am speaking of the magnitude of pleasure; I want to know where pleasures are found to be most intense.
For, as I say, we have to discover what is pleasure, and what they mean by pleasure who deny her very existence.

845.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I think I follow you.

846.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: You will soon have a better opportunity of showing whether you do or not, Protarchus.
Answer now, and tell me whether you see, I will not say more, but more intense and excessive pleasures in wantonness than in temperance?
Reflect before you speak.

847.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I understand you, and see that there is a great difference between them; the temperate are restrained by the wise man's aphorism of 'Never too much,' which is their rule, but excess of pleasure possessing the minds of fools and wantons becomes madness and makes them shout with delight.

848.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Very good, and if this be true, then the greatest pleasures and pains will clearly be found in some vicious state of soul and body, and not in a virtuous state.

849.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

850.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And ought we not to select some of these for examination, and see what makes them the greatest?

851.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: To be sure we ought.

852.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Take the case of the pleasures which arise out of certain disorders.

853.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What disorders?

854.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The pleasures of unseemly disorders, which our severe friends utterly detest.

855.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What pleasures?

856.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Such, for example, as the relief of itching and other ailments by scratching, which is the only remedy required.
For what in Heaven's name is the feeling to be called which is thus produced in us?—Pleasure or pain?

857.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: A villainous mixture of some kind, Socrates, I should say.

858.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I did not introduce the argument, O Protarchus, with any personal reference to Philebus, but because, without the consideration of these and similar pleasures, we shall not be able to determine the point at issue.

859.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Then we had better proceed to analyze this family of pleasures.

860.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: You mean the pleasures which are mingled with pain?

861.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Exactly.

862.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: There are some mixtures which are of the body, and only in the body, and others which are of the soul, and only in the soul; while there are other mixtures of pleasures with pains, common both to soul and body, which in their composite state are called sometimes pleasures and sometimes pains.

863.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How is that?

864.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Whenever, in the restoration or in the derangement of nature, a man experiences two opposite feelings; for example, when he is cold and is growing warm, or again, when he is hot and is becoming cool, and he wants to have the one and be rid of the other;—the sweet has a bitter, as the common saying is, and both together fasten upon him and create irritation and in time drive him to distraction.

865.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That description is very true to nature.

866.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And in these sorts of mixtures the pleasures and pains are sometimes equal, and sometimes one or other of them predominates?

867.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

868.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Of cases in which the pain exceeds the pleasure, an example is afforded by itching, of which we were just now speaking, and by the tingling which we feel when the boiling and fiery element is within, and the rubbing and motion only relieves the surface, and does not reach the parts affected; then if you put them to the fire, and as a last resort apply cold to them, you may often produce the most intense pleasure or pain in the inner parts, which contrasts and mingles with the pain or pleasure, as the case may be, of the outer parts; and this is due to the forcible separation of what is united, or to the union of what is separated, and to the juxtaposition of pleasure and pain.

869.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Quite so.

870.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Sometimes the element of pleasure prevails in a man, and the slight undercurrent of pain makes him tingle, and causes a gentle irritation; or again, the excessive infusion of pleasure creates an excitement in him,—he even leaps for joy, he assumes all sorts of attitudes, he changes all manner of colours, he gasps for breath, and is quite amazed, and utters the most irrational exclamations.

871.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, indeed.

872.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: He will say of himself, and others will say of him, that he is dying with these delights; and the more dissipated and good-for-nothing he is, the more vehemently he pursues them in every way; of all pleasures he declares them to be the greatest; and he reckons him who lives in the most constant enjoyment of them to be the happiest of mankind.

873.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That, Socrates, is a very true description of the opinions of the majority about pleasures.

874.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Yes, Protarchus, quite true of the mixed pleasures, which arise out of the communion of external and internal sensations in the body; there are also cases in which the mind contributes an opposite element to the body, whether of pleasure or pain, and the two unite and form one mixture.
Concerning these I have already remarked, that when a man is empty he desires to be full, and has pleasure in hope and pain in vacuity.
But now I must further add what I omitted before, that in all these and similar emotions in which body and mind are opposed (and they are innumerable), pleasure and pain coalesce in one.

875.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I believe that to be quite true.

876.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: There still remains one other sort of admixture of pleasures and pains.

877.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What is that?

878.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The union which, as we were saying, the mind often experiences of purely mental feelings.

879.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What do you mean?

880.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Why, do we not speak of anger, fear, desire, sorrow, love, emulation, envy, and the like, as pains which belong to the soul only?

881.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

882.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And shall we not find them also full of the most wonderful pleasures?
need I remind you of the anger
'Which stirs even a wise man to violence, And is sweeter than honey and the honeycomb?'
And you remember how pleasures mingle with pains in lamentation and bereavement?

885.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, there is a natural connexion between them.

886.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And you remember also how at the sight of tragedies the spectators smile through their tears?

887.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly I do.

888.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And are you aware that even at a comedy the soul experiences a mixed feeling of pain and pleasure?

889.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I do not quite understand you.

890.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I admit, Protarchus, that there is some difficulty in recognizing this mixture of feelings at a comedy.

891.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: There is, I think.

892.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the greater the obscurity of the case the more desirable is the examination of it, because the difficulty in detecting other cases of mixed pleasures and pains will be less.

893.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Proceed.

894.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I have just mentioned envy; would you not call that a pain of the soul?

895.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

896.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And yet the envious man finds something in the misfortunes of his neighbours at which he is pleased?

897.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

898.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And ignorance, and what is termed clownishness, are surely an evil?

899.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: To be sure.

900.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: From these considerations learn to know the nature of the ridiculous.

901.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Explain.

902.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The ridiculous is in short the specific name which is used to describe the vicious form of a certain habit; and of vice in general it is that kind which is most at variance with the inscription at Delphi.

903.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: You mean, Socrates, 'Know thyself.'

904.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I do; and the opposite would be, 'Know not thyself.'

905.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

906.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now, O Protarchus, try to divide this into three.

907.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Indeed I am afraid that I cannot.

908.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Do you mean to say that I must make the division for you?

909.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, and what is more, I beg that you will.

910.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Are there not three ways in which ignorance of self may be shown?

911.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What are they?

912.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: In the first place, about money; the ignorant may fancy himself richer than he is.

913.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, that is a very common error.

914.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And still more often he will fancy that he is taller or fairer than he is, or that he has some other advantage of person which he really has not.

915.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Of course.

916.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And yet surely by far the greatest number err about the goods of the mind; they imagine themselves to be much better men than they are.

917.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, that is by far the commonest delusion.

918.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And of all the virtues, is not wisdom the one which the mass of mankind are always claiming, and which most arouses in them a spirit of contention and lying conceit of wisdom?

919.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

920.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And may not all this be truly called an evil condition?

921.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very evil.

922.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But we must pursue the division a step further, Protarchus, if we would see in envy of the childish sort a singular mixture of pleasure and pain.

923.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How can we make the further division which you suggest?

924.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: All who are silly enough to entertain this lying conceit of themselves may of course be divided, like the rest of mankind, into two classes—one having power and might; and the other the reverse.

925.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

926.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let this, then, be the principle of division; those of them who are weak and unable to revenge themselves, when they are laughed at, may be truly called ridiculous, but those who can defend themselves may be more truly described as strong and formidable; for ignorance in the powerful is hateful and horrible, because hurtful to others both in reality and in fiction, but powerless ignorance may be reckoned, and in truth is, ridiculous.

927.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That is very true, but I do not as yet see where is the admixture of pleasures and pains.

928.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, then, let us examine the nature of envy.

929.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Proceed.

930.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Is not envy an unrighteous pleasure, and also an unrighteous pain?

931.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Most true.

932.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: There is nothing envious or wrong in rejoicing at the misfortunes of enemies?

933.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly not.

934.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But to feel joy instead of sorrow at the sight of our friends' misfortunes—is not that wrong?

935.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Undoubtedly.

936.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Did we not say that ignorance was always an evil?

937.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

938.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the three kinds of vain conceit in our friends which we enumerated—the vain conceit of beauty, of wisdom, and of wealth, are ridiculous if they are weak, and detestable when they are powerful:  May we not say, as I was saying before, that our friends who are in this state of mind, when harmless to others, are simply ridiculous?

939.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: They are ridiculous.

940.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And do we not acknowledge this ignorance of theirs to be a misfortune?

941.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

942.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And do we feel pain or pleasure in laughing at it?

943.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Clearly we feel pleasure.

944.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And was not envy the source of this pleasure which we feel at the misfortunes of friends?

945.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

946.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then the argument shows that when we laugh at the folly of our friends, pleasure, in mingling with envy, mingles with pain, for envy has been acknowledged by us to be mental pain, and laughter is pleasant; and so we envy and laugh at the same instant.

947.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

948.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the argument implies that there are combinations of pleasure and pain in lamentations, and in tragedy and comedy, not only on the stage, but on the greater stage of human life; and so in endless other cases.

949.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I do not see how any one can deny what you say, Socrates, however eager he may be to assert the opposite opinion.

950.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I mentioned anger, desire, sorrow, fear, love, emulation, envy, and similar emotions, as examples in which we should find a mixture of the two elements so often named; did I not?

951.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

952.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: We may observe that our conclusions hitherto have had reference only to sorrow and envy and anger.

953.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I see.

954.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then many other cases still remain?

955.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

956.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And why do you suppose me to have pointed out to you the admixture which takes place in comedy?

Why but to convince you that there was no difficulty in showing the mixed nature of fear and love and similar affections; and I thought that when I had given you the illustration, you would have let me off, and have acknowledged as a general truth that the body without the soul, and the soul without the body, as well as the two united, are susceptible of all sorts of admixtures of pleasures and pains; and so further discussion would have been unnecessary.
And now I want to know whether I may depart; or will you keep me here until midnight?
I fancy that I may obtain my release without many words;—if I promise that to-morrow I will give you an account of all these cases.
But at present I would rather sail in another direction, and go to other matters which remain to be settled, before the judgment can be given which Philebus demands.

957.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very good, Socrates; in what remains take your own course.

958.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then after the mixed pleasures the unmixed should have their turn; this is the natural and necessary order.

959.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Excellent.

960.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: These, in turn, then, I will now endeavour to indicate; for with the maintainers of the opinion that all pleasures are a cessation of pain, I do not agree, but, as I was saying, I use them as witnesses, that there are pleasures which seem only and are not, and there are others again which have great power and appear in many forms, yet are intermingled with pains, and are partly alleviations of agony and distress, both of body and mind.

961.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Then what pleasures, Socrates, should we be right in conceiving to be true?

962.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: True pleasures are those which are given by beauty of colour and form, and most of those which arise from smells; those of sound, again, and in general those of which the want is painless and unconscious, and of which the fruition is palpable to sense and pleasant and unalloyed with pain.

963.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Once more, Socrates, I must ask what you mean.

964.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: My meaning is certainly not obvious, and I will endeavour to be plainer.

I do not mean by beauty of form such beauty as that of animals or pictures, which the many would suppose to be my meaning; but, says the argument, understand me to mean straight lines and circles, and the plane or solid figures which are formed out of them by turning-lathes and rulers and measurers of angles; for these I affirm to be not only relatively beautiful, like other things, but they are eternally and absolutely beautiful, and they have peculiar pleasures, quite unlike the pleasures of scratching.
And there are colours which are of the same character, and have similar pleasures; now do you understand my meaning?

965.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I am trying to understand, Socrates, and I hope that you will try to make your meaning clearer.

966.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: When sounds are smooth and clear, and have a single pure tone, then I mean to say that they are not relatively but absolutely beautiful, and have natural pleasures associated with them.

967.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, there are such pleasures.

968.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The pleasures of smell are of a less ethereal sort, but they have no necessary admixture of pain; and all pleasures, however and wherever experienced, which are unattended by pains, I assign to an analogous class.
Here then are two kinds of pleasures.

969.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I understand.

970.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: To these may be added the pleasures of knowledge, if no hunger of knowledge and no pain caused by such hunger precede them.

971.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: And this is the case.

972.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, but if a man who is full of knowledge loses his knowledge, are there not pains of forgetting?

973.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Not necessarily, but there may be times of reflection, when he feels grief at the loss of his knowledge.

974.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Yes, my friend, but at present we are enumerating only the natural perceptions, and have nothing to do with reflection.

975.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: In that case you are right in saying that the loss of knowledge is not attended with pain.

976.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: These pleasures of knowledge, then, are unmixed with pain; and they are not the pleasures of the many but of a very few.

977.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Quite true.

978.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now, having fairly separated the pure pleasures and those which may be rightly termed impure, let us further add to our description of them, that the pleasures which are in excess have no measure, but that those which are not in excess have measure; the great, the excessive, whether more or less frequent, we shall be right in referring to the class of the infinite, and of the more and less, which pours through body and soul alike; and the others we shall refer to the class which has measure.

979.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Quite right, Socrates.

980.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Still there is something more to be considered about pleasures.

981.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What is it?

982.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: When you speak of purity and clearness, or of excess, abundance, greatness and sufficiency, in what relation do these terms stand to truth?

983.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Why do you ask, Socrates?

984.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Because, Protarchus, I should wish to test pleasure and knowledge in every possible way, in order that if there be a pure and impure element in either of them, I may present the pure element for judgment, and then they will be more easily judged of by you and by me and by all of us.

985.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Most true.

986.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let us investigate all the pure kinds; first selecting for consideration a single instance.

987.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What instance shall we select?

988.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Suppose that we first of all take whiteness.

989.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very good.

990.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: How can there be purity in whiteness, and what purity?
Is that purest which is greatest or most in quantity, or that which is most unadulterated and freest from any admixture of other colours?

991.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Clearly that which is most unadulterated.

992.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: True, Protarchus; and so the purest white, and not the greatest or largest in quantity, is to be deemed truest and most beautiful?

993.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Right.

994.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And we shall be quite right in saying that a little pure white is whiter and fairer and truer than a great deal that is mixed.

995.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Perfectly right.

996.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: There is no need of adducing many similar examples in illustration of the argument about pleasure; one such is sufficient to prove to us that a small pleasure or a small amount of pleasure, if pure or unalloyed with pain, is always pleasanter and truer and fairer than a great pleasure or a great amount of pleasure of another kind.

997.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Assuredly; and the instance you have given is quite sufficient.

998.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But what do you say of another question: —have we not heard that pleasure is always a generation, and has no true being?
Do not certain ingenious philosophers teach this doctrine, and ought not we to be grateful to them?

999.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What do they mean?

1000.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I will explain to you, my dear Protarchus, what they mean, by putting a question.

1001.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Ask, and I will answer.

1002.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I assume that there are two natures, one self-existent, and the other ever in want of something.

1003.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What manner of natures are they?

1004.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The one majestic ever, the other inferior.

1005.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: You speak riddles.

1006.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: You have seen loves good and fair, and also brave lovers of them.

1007.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I should think so.

1008.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Search the universe for two terms which are like these two and are present everywhere.

1009.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yet a third time I must say, Be a little plainer, Socrates.

1010.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: There is no difficulty, Protarchus; the argument is only in play, and insinuates that some things are for the sake of something else (relatives), and that other things are the ends to which the former class subserve (absolutes).

1011.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Your many repetitions make me slow to understand.

1012.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: As the argument proceeds, my boy, I dare say that the meaning will become clearer.

1013.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very likely.

1014.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Here are two new principles.

1015.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What are they?

1016.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: One is the generation of all things, and the other is essence.

1017.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I readily accept from you both generation and essence.

1018.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Very right; and would you say that generation is for the sake of essence, or essence for the sake of generation?

1019.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: You want to know whether that which is called essence is, properly speaking, for the sake of generation?

1020.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Yes.

1021.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: By the gods, I wish that you would repeat your question.

1022.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I mean, O my Protarchus, to ask whether you would tell me that ship-building is for the sake of ships, or ships for the sake of ship-building?
and in all similar cases I should ask the same question.

1023.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Why do you not answer yourself, Socrates?

1024.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I have no objection, but you must take your part.

1025.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

1026.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: My answer is, that all things instrumental, remedial, material, are given to us with a view to generation, and that each generation is relative to, or for the sake of, some being or essence, and that the whole of generation is relative to the whole of essence.

1027.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Assuredly.

1028.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then pleasure, being a generation, must surely be for the sake of some essence?

1029.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

1030.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And that for the sake of which something else is done must be placed in the class of good, and that which is done for the sake of something else, in some other class, my good friend.

1031.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Most certainly.

1032.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then pleasure, being a generation, will be rightly placed in some other class than that of good?

1033.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Quite right.

1034.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then, as I said at first, we ought to be very grateful to him who first pointed out that pleasure was a generation only, and had no true being at all; for he is clearly one who laughs at the notion of pleasure being a good.

1035.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Assuredly.

1036.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And he would surely laugh also at those who make generation their highest end.

1037.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Of whom are you speaking, and what do they mean?

1038.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I am speaking of those who when they are cured of hunger or thirst or any other defect by some process of generation are delighted at the process as if it were pleasure; and they say that they would not wish to live without these and other feelings of a like kind which might be mentioned.

1039.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That is certainly what they appear to think.

1040.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And is not destruction universally admitted to be the opposite of generation?

1041.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

1042.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then he who chooses thus, would choose generation and destruction rather than that third sort of life, in which, as we were saying, was neither pleasure nor pain, but only the purest possible thought.

1043.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: He who would make us believe pleasure to be a good is involved in great absurdities, Socrates.

1044.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Great, indeed; and there is yet another of them.

1045.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What is it?

1046.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Is there not an absurdity in arguing that there is nothing good or noble in the body, or in anything else, but that good is in the soul only, and that the only good of the soul is pleasure; and that courage or temperance or understanding, or any other good of the soul, is not really a good?—and is there not yet a further absurdity in our being compelled to say that he who has a feeling of pain and not of pleasure is bad at the time when he is suffering pain, even though he be the best of men; and again, that he who has a feeling of pleasure, in so far as he is pleased at the time when he is pleased, in that degree excels in virtue?

1047.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Nothing, Socrates, can be more irrational than all this.

1048.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now, having subjected pleasure to every sort of test, let us not appear to be too sparing of mind and knowledge:  let us ring their metal bravely, and see if there be unsoundness in any part, until we have found out what in them is of the purest nature; and then the truest elements both of pleasure and knowledge may be brought up for judgment.

1049.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Right.

1050.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Knowledge has two parts,—the one productive, and the other educational?

1051.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

1052.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And in the productive or handicraft arts, is not one part more akin to knowledge, and the other less; and may not the one part be regarded as the pure, and the other as the impure?

1053.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

1054.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let us separate the superior or dominant elements in each of them.

1055.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What are they, and how do you separate them?

1056.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I mean to say, that if arithmetic, mensuration, and weighing be taken away from any art, that which remains will not be much.

1057.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Not much, certainly.

1058.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The rest will be only conjecture, and the better use of the senses which is given by experience and practice, in addition to a certain power of guessing, which is commonly called art, and is perfected by attention and pains.

1059.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Nothing more, assuredly.

1060.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Music, for instance, is full of this empiricism; for sounds are harmonized, not by measure, but by skilful conjecture; the music of the flute is always trying to guess the pitch of each vibrating note, and is therefore mixed up with much that is doubtful and has little which is certain.

1061.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Most true.

1062.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the same will be found to hold good of medicine and husbandry and piloting and generalship.

1063.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

1064.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The art of the builder, on the other hand, which uses a number of measures and instruments, attains by their help to a greater degree of accuracy than the other arts.

1065.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How is that?

1066.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: In ship-building and house-building, and in other branches of the art of carpentering, the builder has his rule, lathe, compass, line, and a most ingenious machine for straightening wood.

1067.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true, Socrates.

1068.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then now let us divide the arts of which we were speaking into two kinds,—the arts which, like music, are less exact in their results, and those which, like carpentering, are more exact.

1069.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Let us make that division.

1070.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Of the latter class, the most exact of all are those which we just now spoke of as primary.

1071.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I see that you mean arithmetic, and the kindred arts of weighing and measuring.

1072.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Certainly, Protarchus; but are not these also distinguishable into two kinds?

1073.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What are the two kinds?

1074.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: In the first place, arithmetic is of two kinds, one of which is popular, and the other philosophical.

1075.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How would you distinguish them?

1076.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: There is a wide difference between them, Protarchus; some arithmeticians reckon unequal units; as for example, two armies, two oxen, two very large things or two very small things.
The party who are opposed to them insist that every unit in ten thousand must be the same as every other unit.

1077.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Undoubtedly there is, as you say, a great difference among the votaries of the science; and there may be reasonably supposed to be two sorts of arithmetic.

1078.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And when we compare the art of mensuration which is used in building with philosophical geometry, or the art of computation which is used in trading with exact calculation, shall we say of either of the pairs that it is one or two?

1079.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: On the analogy of what has preceded, I should be of opinion that they were severally two.

1080.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Right; but do you understand why I have discussed the subject?

1081.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I think so, but I should like to be told by you.

1082.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The argument has all along been seeking a parallel to pleasure, and true to that original design, has gone on to ask whether one sort of knowledge is purer than another, as one pleasure is purer than another.

1083.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Clearly; that was the intention.

1084.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And has not the argument in what has preceded, already shown that the arts have different provinces, and vary in their degrees of certainty?

1085.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

1086.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And just now did not the argument first designate a particular art by a common term, thus making us believe in the unity of that art; and then again, as if speaking of two different things, proceed to enquire whether the art as pursed by philosophers, or as pursued by non-philosophers, has more of certainty and purity?

1087.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That is the very question which the argument is asking.

1088.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And how, Protarchus, shall we answer the enquiry?

1089.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: O Socrates, we have reached a point at which the difference of clearness in different kinds of knowledge is enormous.

1090.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then the answer will be the easier.

1091.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly; and let us say in reply, that those arts into which arithmetic and mensuration enter, far surpass all others; and that of these the arts or sciences which are animated by the pure philosophic impulse are infinitely superior in accuracy and truth.

1092.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then this is your judgment; and this is the answer which, upon your authority, we will give to all masters of the art of misinterpretation?

1093.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What answer?

1094.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: That there are two arts of arithmetic, and two of mensuration; and also several other arts which in like manner have this double nature, and yet only one name.

1095.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Let us boldly return this answer to the masters of whom you speak, Socrates, and hope for good luck.

1096.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: We have explained what we term the most exact arts or sciences.

1097.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very good.

1098.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And yet, Protarchus, dialectic will refuse to acknowledge us, if we do not award to her the first place.

1099.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: And pray, what is dialectic?

1100.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Clearly the science which has to do with all that knowledge of which we are now speaking; for I am sure that all men who have a grain of intelligence will admit that the knowledge which has to do with being and reality, and sameness and unchangeableness, is by far the truest of all.
But how would you decide this question, Protarchus?

1101.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I have often heard Gorgias maintain, Socrates, that the art of persuasion far surpassed every other; this, as he says, is by far the best of them all, for to it all things submit, not by compulsion, but of their own free will.
Now, I should not like to quarrel either with you or with him.

1102.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: You mean to say that you would like to desert, if you were not ashamed?

1103.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: As you please.

1104.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: May I not have led you into a misapprehension?

1105.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How?

1106.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Dear Protarchus, I never asked which was the greatest or best or usefullest of arts or sciences, but which had clearness and accuracy, and the greatest amount of truth, however humble and little useful an art.

And as for Gorgias, if you do not deny that his art has the advantage in usefulness to mankind, he will not quarrel with you for saying that the study of which I am speaking is superior in this particular of essential truth; as in the comparison of white colours, a little whiteness, if that little be only pure, was said to be superior in truth to a great mass which is impure.

And now let us give our best attention and consider well, not the comparative use or reputation of the sciences, but the power or faculty, if there be such, which the soul has of loving the truth, and of doing all things for the sake of it; let us search into the pure element of mind and intelligence, and then we shall be able to say whether the science of which I have been speaking is most likely to possess the faculty, or whether there be some other which has higher claims.

1107.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Well, I have been considering, and I can hardly think that any other science or art has a firmer grasp of the truth than this.

1108.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Do you say so because you observe that the arts in general and those engaged in them make use of opinion, and are resolutely engaged in the investigation of matters of opinion?
Even he who supposes himself to be occupied with nature is really occupied with the things of this world, how created, how acting or acted upon.
Is not this the sort of enquiry in which his life is spent?

1109.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

1110.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: He is labouring, not after eternal being, but about things which are becoming, or which will or have become.

1111.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

1112.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And can we say that any of these things which neither are nor have been nor will be unchangeable, when judged by the strict rule of truth ever become certain?

1113.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Impossible.

1114.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: How can anything fixed be concerned with that which has no fixedness?

1115.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How indeed?

1116.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then mind and science when employed about such changing things do not attain the highest truth?

1117.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I should imagine not.

1118.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now let us bid farewell, a long farewell, to you or me or Philebus or Gorgias, and urge on behalf of the argument a single point.

1119.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What point?

1120.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let us say that the stable and pure and true and unalloyed has to do with the things which are eternal and unchangeable and unmixed, or if not, at any rate what is most akin to them has; and that all other things are to be placed in a second or inferior class.

1121.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

1122.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And of the names expressing cognition, ought not the fairest to be given to the fairest things?

1123.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: That is natural.

1124.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And are not mind and wisdom the names which are to be honoured most?

1125.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

1126.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And these names may be said to have their truest and most exact application when the mind is engaged in the contemplation of true being?

1127.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

1128.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And these were the names which I adduced of the rivals of pleasure?

1129.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true, Socrates.

1130.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: In the next place, as to the mixture, here are the ingredients, pleasure and wisdom, and we may be compared to artists who have their materials ready to their hands.

1131.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes.

1132.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now we must begin to mix them?

1133.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: By all means.

1134.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But had we not better have a preliminary word and refresh our memories?

1135.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Of what?

1136.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Of that which I have already mentioned.
Well says the proverb, that we ought to repeat twice and even thrice that which is good.

1137.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

1138.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well then, by Zeus, let us proceed, and I will make what I believe to be a fair summary of the argument.

1139.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Let me hear.

1140.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Philebus says that pleasure is the true end of all living beings, at which all ought to aim, and moreover that it is the chief good of all, and that the two names 'good' and 'pleasant' are correctly given to one thing and one nature; Socrates, on the other hand, begins by denying this, and further says, that in nature as in name they are two, and that wisdom partakes more than pleasure of the good.
Is not and was not this what we were saying, Protarchus?

1141.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

1142.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And is there not and was there not a further point which was conceded between us?

1143.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What was it?

1144.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: That the good differs from all other things.

1145.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: In what respect?

1146.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: In that the being who possesses good always everywhere and in all things has the most perfect sufficiency, and is never in need of anything else.

1147.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Exactly.

1148.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And did we not endeavour to make an imaginary separation of wisdom and pleasure, assigning to each a distinct life, so that pleasure was wholly excluded from wisdom, and wisdom in like manner had no part whatever in pleasure?

1149.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: We did.

1150.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And did we think that either of them alone would be sufficient?

1151.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly not.

1152.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if we erred in any point, then let any one who will, take up the enquiry again and set us right; and assuming memory and wisdom and knowledge and true opinion to belong to the same class, let him consider whether he would desire to possess or acquire,—I will not say pleasure, however abundant or intense, if he has no real perception that he is pleased, nor any consciousness of what he feels, nor any recollection, however momentary, of the feeling,—but would he desire to have anything at all, if these faculties were wanting to him?

And about wisdom I ask the same question; can you conceive that any one would choose to have all wisdom absolutely devoid of pleasure, rather than with a certain degree of pleasure, or all pleasure devoid of wisdom, rather than with a certain degree of wisdom?

1153.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly not, Socrates; but why repeat such questions any more?

1154.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then the perfect and universally eligible and entirely good cannot possibly be either of them?

1155.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Impossible.

1156.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then now we must ascertain the nature of the good more or less accurately, in order, as we were saying, that the second place may be duly assigned.

1157.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Right.

1158.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Have we not found a road which leads towards the good?

1159.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What road?

1160.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Supposing that a man had to be found, and you could discover in what house he lived, would not that be a great step towards the discovery of the man himself?

1161.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

1162.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now reason intimates to us, as at our first beginning, that we should seek the good, not in the unmixed life but in the mixed.

1163.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

1164.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: There is greater hope of finding that which we are seeking in the life which is well mixed than in that which is not?

1165.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Far greater.

1166.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then now let us mingle, Protarchus, at the same time offering up a prayer to Dionysus or Hephaestus, or whoever is the god who presides over the ceremony of mingling.

1167.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: By all means.

1168.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Are not we the cup-bearers?

and here are two fountains which are flowing at our side:  one, which is pleasure, may be likened to a fountain of honey; the other, wisdom, a sober draught in which no wine mingles, is of water unpleasant but healthful; out of these we must seek to make the fairest of all possible mixtures.

1169.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

1170.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Tell me first;—should we be most likely to succeed if we mingled every sort of pleasure with every sort of wisdom?

1171.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Perhaps we might.

1172.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But I should be afraid of the risk, and I think that I can show a safer plan.

1173.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What is it?

1174.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: One pleasure was supposed by us to be truer than another, and one art to be more exact than another.

1175.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

1176.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: There was also supposed to be a difference in sciences; some of them regarding only the transient and perishing, and others the permanent and imperishable and everlasting and immutable; and when judged by the standard of truth, the latter, as we thought, were truer than the former.

1177.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very good and right.

1178.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: If, then, we were to begin by mingling the sections of each class which have the most of truth, will not the union suffice to give us the loveliest of lives, or shall we still want some elements of another kind?

1179.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I think that we ought to do what you suggest.

1180.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let us suppose a man who understands justice, and has reason as well as understanding about the true nature of this and of all other things.

1181.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: We will suppose such a man.

1182.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Will he have enough of knowledge if he is acquainted only with the divine circle and sphere, and knows nothing of our human spheres and circles, but uses only divine circles and measures in the building of a house?

1183.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: The knowledge which is only superhuman, Socrates, is ridiculous in man.

1184.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: What do you mean?
Do you mean that you are to throw into the cup and mingle the impure and uncertain art which uses the false measure and the false circle?

1185.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, we must, if any of us is ever to find his way home.

1186.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And am I to include music, which, as I was saying just now, is full of guesswork and imitation, and is wanting in purity?

1187.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, I think that you must, if human life is to be a life at all.

1188.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, then, suppose that I give way, and, like a doorkeeper who is pushed and overborne by the mob, I open the door wide, and let knowledge of every sort stream in, and the pure mingle with the impure?

1189.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I do not know, Socrates, that any great harm would come of having them all, if only you have the first sort.

1190.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, then, shall I let them all flow into what Homer poetically terms 'a meeting of the waters'?

1191.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: By all means.

1192.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: There—I have let them in, and now I must return to the fountain of pleasure.

For we were not permitted to begin by mingling in a single stream the true portions of both according to our original intention; but the love of all knowledge constrained us to let all the sciences flow in together before the pleasures.

1193.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Quite true.

1194.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now the time has come for us to consider about the pleasures also, whether we shall in like manner let them go all at once, or at first only the true ones.

1195.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: It will be by far the safer course to let flow the true ones first.

1196.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let them flow, then; and now, if there are any necessary pleasures, as there were arts and sciences necessary, must we not mingle them?

1197.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes; the necessary pleasures should certainly be allowed to mingle.

1198.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The knowledge of the arts has been admitted to be innocent and useful always; and if we say of pleasures in like manner that all of them are good and innocent for all of us at all times, we must let them all mingle?

1199.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What shall we say about them, and what course shall we take?

1200.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Do not ask me, Protarchus; but ask the daughters of pleasure and wisdom to answer for themselves.

1201.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How?

1202.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Tell us, O beloved—shall we call you pleasures or by some other name?—would you rather live with or without wisdom?
I am of opinion that they would certainly answer as follows:

1203.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How?

1204.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: They would answer, as we said before, that for any single class to be left by itself pure and isolated is not good, nor altogether possible; and that if we are to make comparisons of one class with another and choose, there is no better companion than knowledge of things in general, and likewise the perfect knowledge, if that may be, of ourselves in every respect.

1205.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: And our answer will be: —In that ye have spoken well.

1206.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Very true.
And now let us go back and interrogate wisdom and mind:  Would you like to have any pleasures in the mixture?
And they will reply: —'What pleasures do you mean?'

1207.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Likely enough.

1208.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And we shall take up our parable and say:  Do you wish to have the greatest and most vehement pleasures for your companions in addition to the true ones?
'Why, Socrates,' they will say, 'how can we?

seeing that they are the source of ten thousand hindrances to us; they trouble the souls of men, which are our habitation, with their madness; they prevent us from coming to the birth, and are commonly the ruin of the children which are born to us, causing them to be forgotten and unheeded; but the true and pure pleasures, of which you spoke, know to be of our family, and also those pleasures which accompany health and temperance, and which every Virtue, like a goddess, has in her train to follow her about wherever she goes,—mingle these and not the others; there would be great want of sense in any one who desires to see a fair and perfect mixture, and to find in it what is the highest good in man and in the universe, and to divine what is the true form of good—there would be great want of sense in his allowing the pleasures, which are always in the company of folly and vice, to mingle with mind in the cup.
'—Is not this a very rational and suitable reply, which mind has made, both on her own behalf, as well as on the behalf of memory and true opinion?

1209.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Most certainly.

1210.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And still there must be something more added, which is a necessary ingredient in every mixture.

1211.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What is that?

1212.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Unless truth enter into the composition, nothing can truly be created or subsist.

1213.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Impossible.

1214.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Quite impossible; and now you and Philebus must tell me whether anything is still wanting in the mixture, for to my way of thinking the argument is now completed, and may be compared to an incorporeal law, which is going to hold fair rule over a living body.

1215.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I agree with you, Socrates.

1216.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And may we not say with reason that we are now at the vestibule of the habitation of the good?

1217.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I think that we are.

1218.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: What, then, is there in the mixture which is most precious, and which is the principal cause why such a state is universally beloved by all?
When we have discovered it, we will proceed to ask whether this omnipresent nature is more akin to pleasure or to mind.

1219.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Quite right; in that way we shall be better able to judge.

1220.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And there is no difficulty in seeing the cause which renders any mixture either of the highest value or of none at all.

1221.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What do you mean?

1222.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Every man knows it.

1223.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: What?

1224.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: He knows that any want of measure and symmetry in any mixture whatever must always of necessity be fatal, both to the elements and to the mixture, which is then not a mixture, but only a confused medley which brings confusion on the possessor of it.

1225.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Most true.

1226.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now the power of the good has retired into the region of the beautiful; for measure and symmetry are beauty and virtue all the world over.

1227.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

1228.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Also we said that truth was to form an element in the mixture.

1229.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

1230.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then, if we are not able to hunt the good with one idea only, with three we may catch our prey; Beauty, Symmetry, Truth are the three, and these taken together we may regard as the single cause of the mixture, and the mixture as being good by reason of the infusion of them.

1231.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Quite right.

1232.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now, Protarchus, any man could decide well enough whether pleasure or wisdom is more akin to the highest good, and more honourable among gods and men.

1233.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Clearly, and yet perhaps the argument had better be pursued to the end.

1234.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: We must take each of them separately in their relation to pleasure and mind, and pronounce upon them; for we ought to see to which of the two they are severally most akin.

1235.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: You are speaking of beauty, truth, and measure?

1236.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Yes, Protarchus, take truth first, and, after passing in review mind, truth, pleasure, pause awhile and make answer to yourself—as to whether pleasure or mind is more akin to truth.

1237.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: There is no need to pause, for the difference between them is palpable; pleasure is the veriest impostor in the world; and it is said that in the pleasures of love, which appear to be the greatest, perjury is excused by the gods; for pleasures, like children, have not the least particle of reason in them; whereas mind is either the same as truth, or the most like truth, and the truest.

1238.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Shall we next consider measure, in like manner, and ask whether pleasure has more of this than wisdom, or wisdom than pleasure?

1239.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Here is another question which may be easily answered; for I imagine that nothing can ever be more immoderate than the transports of pleasure, or more in conformity with measure than mind and knowledge.

1240.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Very good; but there still remains the third test:  Has mind a greater share of beauty than pleasure, and is mind or pleasure the fairer of the two?

1241.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: No one, Socrates, either awake or dreaming, ever saw or imagined mind or wisdom to be in aught unseemly, at any time, past, present, or future.

1242.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Right.

1243.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: But when we see some one indulging in pleasures, perhaps in the greatest of pleasures, the ridiculous or disgraceful nature of the action makes us ashamed; and so we put them out of sight, and consign them to darkness, under the idea that they ought not to meet the eye of day.

1244.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then, Protarchus, you will proclaim everywhere, by word of mouth to this company, and by messengers bearing the tidings far and wide, that pleasure is not the first of possessions, nor yet the second, but that in measure, and the mean, and the suitable, and the like, the eternal nature has been found.

1245.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Yes, that seems to be the result of what has been now said.

1246.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: In the second class is contained the symmetrical and beautiful and perfect or sufficient, and all which are of that family.

1247.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

1248.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if you reckon in the third class mind and wisdom, you will not be far wrong, if I divine aright.

1249.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I dare say.

1250.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And would you not put in the fourth class the goods which we were affirming to appertain specially to the soul—sciences and arts and true opinions as we called them?
These come after the third class, and form the fourth, as they are certainly more akin to good than pleasure is.

1251.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Surely.

1252.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The fifth class are the pleasures which were defined by us as painless, being the pure pleasures of the soul herself, as we termed them, which accompany, some the sciences, and some the senses.

1253.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Perhaps.

1254.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now, as Orpheus says,

sentences.0: 'With the sixth generation cease the glory of my song.'

sentences: Here, at the sixth award, let us make an end; all that remains is to set the crown on our discourse.

1257.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

1258.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then let us sum up and reassert what has been said, thus offering the third libation to the saviour Zeus.

1259.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: How?

1260.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Philebus affirmed that pleasure was always and absolutely the good.

1261.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: I understand; this third libation, Socrates, of which you spoke, meant a recapitulation.

1262.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Yes, but listen to the sequel; convinced of what I have just been saying, and feeling indignant at the doctrine, which is maintained, not by Philebus only, but by thousands of others, I affirmed that mind was far better and far more excellent, as an element of human life, than pleasure.

1263.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

1264.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But, suspecting that there were other things which were also better, I went on to say that if there was anything better than either, then I would claim the second place for mind over pleasure, and pleasure would lose the second place as well as the first.

1265.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: You did.

1266.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Nothing could be more satisfactorily shown than the unsatisfactory nature of both of them.

1267.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Very true.

1268.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The claims both of pleasure and mind to be the absolute good have been entirely disproven in this argument, because they are both wanting in self-sufficiency and also in adequacy and perfection.

1269.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Most true.

1270.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But, though they must both resign in favour of another, mind is ten thousand times nearer and more akin to the nature of the conqueror than pleasure.

1271.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: Certainly.

1272.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And, according to the judgment which has now been given, pleasure will rank fifth.

1273.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: True.

1274.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But not first; no, not even if all the oxen and horses and animals in the world by their pursuit of enjoyment proclaim her to be so;—although the many trusting in them, as diviners trust in birds, determine that pleasures make up the good of life, and deem the lusts of animals to be better witnesses than the inspirations of divine philosophy.

1275.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: And now, Socrates, we tell you that the truth of what you have been saying is approved by the judgment of all of us.

1276.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And will you let me go?

1277.speaker: PROTARCHUS
sentences: There is a little which yet remains, and I will remind you of it, for I am sure that you will not be the first to go away from an argument.
